title: The New Kid in Robotics Club

chapters.text: Jake stood frozen at the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. The room buzzed with the sounds of small motors and excited chatter that instantly died when he appeared. A tall girl with bright blue hair stepped forward. "You lost?" she asked, raising an eyebrow. Jake swallowed hard. After being the new kid at three schools in two years, he'd promised himself this time would be different. He'd make real friends here. "Actually, I signed up for robotics," he said, trying to sound confident. The girl's serious expression suddenly cracked into a wide grin. "Perfect! We need someone who knows coding." Jake relaxed slightly, not mentioning that he'd exaggerated his skills on the sign-up sheet. How hard could it be? Surely his new friendship wouldn't fall apart when they discovered the truth.

Jake took a deep breath and stepped further into the robotics club room. The other students returned to their projects, the moment of awkward staring finally over. Ms. Chen, the club advisor, waved him over to where Amir was working on a small robot that could follow lines on the floor. "Hey, I saved you a seat," Amir said, sliding a chair out. Jake sat down, noticing a carton of chocolate milk on the table that Amir had brought for him. "Thanks," Jake mumbled, surprised by the kind gesture. As they worked together on the robot's sensors, Jake felt his nervousness fade away. Maybe he didn't need to worry so much about his secret - that he had never actually built a robot before and had only joined because his mom made him try a new activity. The way Amir patiently explained each step made Jake think that maybe, just maybe, this club could become something he truly enjoyed.

Jake watched as Amir's hands moved confidently over the circuit board, connecting wires and explaining how the robot's sensors would work. The robotics room buzzed with activity around them, but Jake focused only on Amir's instructions. "See? Now the LED lights up when the sensor detects movement," Amir said, demonstrating with a wave of his hand. Jake nodded and tried it himself, feeling a rush of excitement when the light blinked in response to his movement. Other club members worked on their own projects nearby, occasionally glancing over with approving nods. Jake noticed a trophy shelf in the corner of the room where several shiny awards sat, including a large golden CROWN from last year's state competition. For the first time since walking through that doorway, Jake's shoulders relaxed and a small smile formed on his face as he turned back to their robot.

Jake and Mia worked together for the next hour, their hands moving quickly as they connected wires and adjusted gears. The robot was starting to take shape - a small vehicle with arms that could pick up objects. When Mr. Chen announced it was time to test their creations, Jake felt nervous again. Other teams had fancy robots with blinking lights and smooth movements. Their simple machine looked plain in comparison. "Maybe we should add some protection," Mia suggested, grabbing a small plastic dome from the supply shelf. "Like a helmet for the control panel." Jake nodded, carefully attaching the cover over the sensitive electronics. When they placed their robot on the testing field, it moved perfectly, picking up all the target objects while other fancier robots got stuck or tipped over. The whole club cheered, and Jake couldn't stop grinning as Mr. Chen gave them a thumbs up.

Jake relaxed his grip on his backpack as Chen's thumbs up seemed to break the tension in the room. The other robotics club members began to smile and nod, some even waving at Jake to come further inside. He took a deep breath and stepped forward, his sneakers squeaking slightly on the polished floor. The classroom was filled with tables covered in robot parts, tools, and half-finished projects. Colorful wires spilled across workspaces, and a small testing arena sat in the corner. Jake noticed a fluffy cat sticker on Chen's notebook that reminded him of a paw print. The club president, a tall girl with glasses, walked over and handed Jake a name tag. "Welcome to Robotics Club," she said, pointing to an empty seat next to Chen. "We're building maze-solving robots today, and we could use another team member."

Jake's eyes widened with excitement as he loosened his grip on his backpack. "Maze-solving robots?" he repeated, his voice steadier than before. The tall girl with curly hair nodded and gestured toward an empty seat at her table, where parts and tools were scattered across the surface. Jake shuffled forward, carefully placing his backpack on the floor beside the chair. The other students returned to their work, the buzz of conversation and clicking of plastic parts filling the room. A boy across the table slid a sheet of paper toward Jake, showing a simple diagram of their robot design. "I'm Mia, and that's Ethan," the curly-haired girl said, handing Jake a small motor. "We need someone to help with the sensor programming." Jake picked up the motor, turning it over in his hands as a smile spread across his face. Maybe this club wouldn't be so scary after all.

Jake took a deep breath and stepped into the robotics club room. The other students smiled and waved, making space for him at one of the workbenches. Ms. Rodriguez, the club advisor, handed him a small robot kit. "Welcome to the team, Jake," she said warmly. Over the next hour, Jake learned how to connect wires and program simple commands. When his robot finally moved across the table, everyone cheered. A girl named Mia showed him how to make the robot turn in circles, while Carlos taught him about sensors. By the end of the meeting, Jake had made three new friends and couldn't wait to come back next week. As everyone packed up, Ms. Rodriguez announced their upcoming competition. Jake smiled to himself as he carefully placed his half-finished robot in the storage cabinet. He had found his place at his new school at last.
